Scope
—State and regional networks
were developing, both for instruc¬
tional television and adult pro¬
grams. Networks linked by coaxial
or microwave transmission or by
videotape exchange are in opera¬
tion in Alabama, Oregon, North
Carolina, Florida, and part of New
England. Others are being organ¬
ized with assistance of grants from
the Foundation among colleges and
universities in Michigan, thirteen
Western states, six states in the Up¬
per Midwest, and central Texas.
—The Midwest Program on Air¬
borne Television Instruction was
preparing to telecast courses six
hours a day, four days a week from
an airplane flying over Indiana.
Beginning in September, 1961, the
telecasts will cover an area includ¬
ing 13,000 schools and colleges en¬
rolling five million students.

perts from government, journalism, and academic
research centers in a series on key decisions in

Children’s Programs—The “Children’s Corner”
series, a whimsical world of imaginary friends
like Daniel S. Tiger, who lives in a clock; Grand-
pere, who speaks only French; and the dignified
King Clock, who is in charge of all dates_“Dis¬
covery, ’ ’ in which Mary Lela Grimes, former staff
member of the Massachusetts Audubon Society,
provides the scientific background for youngsters
to explore such topics as ‘ ‘ The Edge of the Sea, ’ ’
“Life’s Building Blocks: Cells,” and “Before
Backbones: Early Invertebrates.” ... “What’s
New,” an experimental series in which leading
child psychologists and educators have collab¬
orated with television specialists, is composed of
fifteen-minute programs covering topics like ani¬
mals, science, drama, health, sports, and the home.
The series runs five days a week for thirteen weeks.
Science and Medicine—‘Frontier to Space,” de¬
veloped by the Physical Science Laboratory of
New Mexico College of Agriculture and Mechanic
Arts. . . . “The Elements,” a series conducted by
the Nobel prize-winning chemist, Dr. Glenn T.
Seaborg....“ The Nature of Viruses, ’ ’ an eight-part
series conducted by another Nobel laureate, Dr.
Wendell M. Stanley of the University of California.
Social Sciences—“The Measure of Man,” lectures
probing such human ideals as loyalty and dignity
and including readings ranging from Euripides to
Thurber....“45 Years with Fitzpatrick,” a series
with the St. Louis Post-Dispatch’s dean of Ameri¬
can political cartoonists....“ Our Nation’s Roots, ’ ’
a series produced by New York University on im¬
migrants and their contributions to the United
States.... “ The Great Plains Trilogy, ’ ’ a Univer¬
sity of Nebraska production dealing with geology,
the Plains Indians, and the westward movement.
...“Religions of Man,” a survey of the great
living religions, their founders, teachings, and
meaning.
